content: one of the most asked questions I get is
what are some ways you can keep the tiles from moving around on the table
get involved personally I've never had an issue with this but I figured I'd go
ahead and try and address it we're going to use magnets I'm not the first person
to try this BMG did it his was sort of a retrofit figured I'd
show you how I would do it integrating it into the tile itself so let's get to
it so the key here is this adhesive magnetic sheeting available at most any
craft store this was about three bucks so this year that I'm using is about a
millimeter thick and so I'll round off another half millimeter for construction
error to give me 61 millimeters so recall from episode 2 that your
foundation is the double corrugated base of the tile so I'll cut 61 millimeter
squares for my foundations then cut strips of the magnetic sheeting these
should be 61 millimeters long and about a quarter of an inch tall now the idea
is simply that instead of using our normal thin cardstock for corrugation
cladding we instead just use the magnetic strip so hot glue them onto all
four sides and you can check that the tile is two
and a half inches in both directions now if you recall from episode three this
means our walls have to be done a little differently since they aren't directly
attached to the corrugation anymore it's a pretty simple adjustment cut half
inch wide strips of chipboard and dollar-store foam board peel the paper
from the foam and hot glue it to the chipboard
apply your wall texture just as we did in Episode three and then simply hot
glue the whole thing to the edge of the tile making sure that it's flush with a
magnet on the outside
from here you prepare and attach the actual game spaces exactly as we did
back in episodes two and three or you can watch my livestream in which I built
a full dungeon tile totally from scratch I'll put a card on the screen with a
link to it and before we go to the table I'd like to take a moment to thank all
wcv sponsors this week I draw your attention to dungeon cast by Dan vicini
Dan's designs are full on custom resin casts he's currently focusing on one and
a quarter inch grid tiles destined for box sets with valuable D&D scenarios in
them basically an evening in a box so click the link in the description below
and check out the dungeon cast Facebook page here we go
so they snap together pretty well of course I bought this really cheap thin
magnetic sheet I did see some thicker much stronger stuff that was like a roll
instead of a sheet at the store so depending on how rowdy your players are
you can attach stronger stuff and polarity is not a problem
clip-on features of course still work fine and I just realized that I forgot
